description: Dive into the physics of sound, light, and the behavior of waves.

slides.title: What is a Wave?
slides.content:
# Energy in Motion üåä

A **Wave** is a disturbance that transfers energy from one place to another without transporting matter.

- **Mechanical Waves**: Need a medium (Sound, Water).
- **Electromagnetic Waves**: No medium needed (Light, Radio).

slides.title: Wave Properties
slides.content:
# Measuring Waves üìè

- **Wavelength ($\lambda$)**: Distance between peaks.
- **Amplitude ($A$)**: Height of the wave (energy).
- **Frequency ($f$)**: Cycles per second (Hertz, $Hz$).
- **Period ($T$)**: Time for one cycle ($T = 1/f$).

**The Wave Equation:**
$$v = f \lambda$$

slides.title: Types of Waves
slides.content:
# Directions of Wiggle „Ä∞Ô∏è

1. **Transverse Waves**: Particles move perpendicular to wave direction. (e.g., Light, Guitar string).
2. **Longitudinal Waves**: Particles move parallel to wave direction. (e.g., Sound, P-waves).

slides.title: Sound Waves
slides.content:
# Hearing Vibrations üîä

Sound is a **Longitudinal Mechanical Wave**.
- Needs a medium (air, water, solid).
- Speed of sound in air $\approx 343 m/s$.
- **Pitch** depends on Frequency.
- **Loudness** depends on Amplitude.

slides.title: Doppler Effect
slides.content:
# eeeeeeerrrrrroooooom üèçÔ∏è

The apparent change in frequency of a wave due to relative motion between source and observer.

- **Approaching**: Frequency increases (Higher pitch).
- **Receding**: Frequency decreases (Lower pitch).

Used in police radar and measuring galaxy speeds!

slides.title: Wave Basics Check
slides.quizQuestion: Which property of a sound wave corresponds to its volume?

slides.title: The Nature of Light
slides.content:
# Particle or Wave? ü§î

Light behaves as **BOTH**!
- **Wave Theory**: Explains interference, diffraction.
- **Particle Theory**: Explains photoelectric effect (Photons).

Light travels in straight lines (Rays) in a uniform medium.

slides.title: Reflection
slides.content:
# Bouncing Back ü™û

**Law of Reflection:**
Measured from the normal line (perpendicular to surface).

$$\theta_{incident} = \theta_{reflected}$$

- **Specular**: Smooth surface, clear image (Mirror).
- **Diffuse**: Rough surface, scattered light (Paper).

slides.title: Refraction
slides.content:
# Bending Light ‚úèÔ∏è

Bending of light when passing from one medium to another (e.g., air to water).

**Snell's Law:**
$$n_1 \sin(\theta_1) = n_2 \sin(\theta_2)$$

- $n$: Index of refraction (measure of optical density).
- Light slows down and bends **towards normal** in denser media.

slides.title: Lenses
slides.content:
# Focusing Light üîç

1. **Convex Lens (Converging)**: Thicker in middle. Focuses light to a point. Used in cameras, eyes.
2. **Concave Lens (Diverging)**: Thinner in middle. Spreads light out. Used for correcting nearsightedness.

slides.title: Total Internal Reflection
slides.content:
# Trapped Light üíé

If light hits a boundary at a steep enough angle (Critical Angle) going from dense $\to$ less dense, it reflects entirely!

Applications:
- **Fiber Optics**: Internet cables.
- **Diamonds**: Sparkle.

slides.title: Interference
slides.content:
# Waves Colliding üí•

When waves overlap:
1. **Constructive**: Peak meets Peak. Amplitude adds up (Louder/Brighter).
2. **Destructive**: Peak meets Trough. Cancel out (Silence/Darkness).

This creates interaction patterns.

slides.title: Diffraction
slides.content:
# Bending Around Corners üö™

The bending of waves around obstacles or through openings.

- Significant when opening size $\approx$ wavelength.
- Why you can hear someone around a corner but can't see them (Sound $\lambda$ is big, Light $\lambda$ is tiny).

slides.title: Optics Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Why does a straw look broken in a glass of water?

slides.title: Dispersion
slides.content:
# Rainbows üåà

Separation of white light into colors.
- Different colors have different wavelengths.
- Refractive index ($n$) varies slightly by wavelength.
- Violet bends most, Red bends least.

Prisms and raindrops cause dispersion.

slides.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
slides.content:
# The Full Picture üìª‚ò¢Ô∏è

From low energy to high energy:
1. Radio Waves
2. Microwaves
3. Infrared
4. Visible Light (ROYGBIV)
5. Ultraviolet
6. X-Rays
7. Gamma Rays

slides.title: Polarization
slides.content:
# Filtering Light üï∂Ô∏è

Light waves oscillate in all directions. **Polarization** restricts vibrations to a single plane.

- Polarized Sunglasses: Block horizontal glare from roads or water.

slides.title: Mirrors
slides.content:
# Image Formation ü™û

- **Plane Mirror**: Virtual, upright, same size.
- **Concave Mirror**: Can magnify or flip image (Makeup mirror).
- **Convex Mirror**: Wide field of view (Store security mirror).

slides.title: Waves Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- Waves transfer **energy**.
- **Sound** is mechanical; **Light** is electromagnetic.
- **Refraction** bends light; **Reflection** bounces it.
- Waves can interfere, diffract, and disperse.

From the music we hear to the colors we see, waves explain our sensory world!
